ratings.comment: I had Scott for ProCom this past semester, and I thought he was hilarious. Most people seemed to not like his sense of humor, but I personally loved it. With the new overhaul of the ProCom classes, I think he did a wonderful job testing to see what works and what doesn't. As long as you participate and go to class, you're golden with Scott.

For a man who teaches professional communication, this man is pretty awkward. He has a unique sense of humor that is very hit-or-miss. Other interesting qualities include admitting his assignments have no practical application in the business world and leaving the classroom for significant periods of time. Not a hard class, just generic and boring.

Take ProCom over the summer. Although it is the worst 3 weeks ever you get it over with and only focus on what's actually important. His assignments are a little vague but if you ask him he is very helpful. Great sense of humor and overall cool guy.

A lot of people shrug this class off as an easy A (and it pretty much is) but if you put the effort into it, you get way more out of the class than you thought you would. His feedback on presentation evaluations is very helpful. He's such a nice guy too - brought the class bagels on one of the last days of class. Easy class, but great guy.

He presents some information in class that is helpful for the real world, but his directions for assignments are vague.  Asking questions about what he wants for projects helps, but sometimes it still felt like I didn't know if I was doing the project right.  He is an easy grader as long as you put in decent effort.  There is a lot of busywork.

The class is very easy, but it is a lot of useless work. I took this class really wanting to get some valuable information, but just prepare yourself to do work and presentations and not learn very much.

The class was horrible and his jokes are bad.  The slides, course packet, and textbook (Dilbert comics) taught me absolutely nothing.  No idea how he does the grading.  However, he gives out the most A's and has minimal work, so I would encourage everyone to take pro comm with him.

His entire class is supposed to be on how to professionally communicate, but he is one of the most unprofessional communicators I have ever met.  He changes due dates frequently, has a million typos in his course packet, and hardly gives you any time to work on your presentations.  Grading is extremely ambiguous.  I have no idea how I got an A.

Changes due dates without telling the class, frequently uses year-old slides without updating the dates, goes off on tangents and poor-taste jokes, never seems prepared for class. A great example of how not to professionally communicate.
good professor, fair grader and valuable feedback on writing and speaking
One of my favorite professors ever.  He creates a great classroom atmosphere.
One of the worst teachers I ever had.  If you could call him a teacher.
His dry humor is great, and his laid-back attitude helps to keep the mood light.  His feedback is priceless, and he was undoubtedly one of the best teachers I have ever had.
